scope.rules_of_engagement: no Dos. scan for open ports. search for vulnerabilties. test vulnerabilities.

notes.text: Home audit completed. Router=Netgear Orbi RBE362 (10.168.168.1), FW=unknown, WiFi=Unknown, Devices~7, DNS=Other/Unknown.
Home audit completed. Router=Netgear Orbi RBE362 (10.168.168.1), FW=V12.1.3.11_5.1.12, WiFi=WPA2, Devices~6-10, DNS=Router DNS filtering.

Home audit completed. Router=Netgear Orbi RBE361 (10.168.168.1), FW=V12.1.13_5.1.12, WiFi=WPA2, Devices~7, DNS=Router DNS filtering.

findings.title: Router Admin Credential Risk (Okay but reused)
findings.description: Router admin password was assessed as 'Okay but reused'. Weak, reused, or unverified admin credentials increase compromise risk.
findings.business_impact: Compromised router credentials can lead to DNS hijacking, traffic interception, and persistent access to the network.
findings.evidence: Password strength selected: Okay but reused
findings.recommendation: Set a unique strong admin password (password manager); enable MFA if available; disable admin access from Wi-Fi guest networks.

findings.title: Guest Network Not Enabled
findings.description: Guest Wi-Fi is not enabled. Without a guest network, visitors often share the main network, increasing exposure of personal devices and IoT assets.
findings.business_impact: Visitors’ devices may introduce malware or insecure services into the same network as sensitive devices.
findings.recommendation: Enable guest Wi-Fi; isolate guests from LAN; use strong password; rotate periodically.

findings.title: IoT Devices Not Segmented/Isolated
findings.description: IoT devices are not isolated from main devices. IoT devices commonly have weaker security and can become pivot points.
findings.business_impact: Compromise of one IoT device can enable lateral movement to personal computers, NAS devices, and phones.
findings.recommendation: Create separate IoT SSID/VLAN; block IoT → LAN by default; allow only required outbound access.

findings.title: Router Web Administration Interface Accessible on LAN
findings.description: Router admin interface is reachable on the local network over HTTP/HTTPS. If any LAN device is compromised (or a guest joins), this increases the chance of router takeover attempts (password guessing, session hijack, known CVEs, etc.).
findings.business_impact: Accessed via HTTP (port 80) and HTTPS (port 443). Admin login page tested and accessible from any LAN device.
findings.evidence: nmap -Pn -T4 --top-ports 1000 10.168.168.1 shows TCP/80 and TCP/443 open; admin UI reachable from LAN; login username observed as “admin”.
findings.recommendation: Router compromise can enable DNS hijacking, traffic interception, device redirection, and persistence across the home network.
